title: RAD: Training an End-to-End Driving Policy via Large-Scale 3DGS-based Reinforcement Learning
author: Hao Gao (Huazhong University of Science & Technology), Shaoyu Chen (Horizon Robotics), Bo Jiang (Huazhong University of Science & Technology), Bencheng Liao (Huazhong University of Science & Technology), Yiang Shi (Huazhong University of Science & Technology), Xiaoyang Guo (Horizon Robotics), ..., Xinggang Wang (Huazhong University of Science & Technology)
relevance_why: The integration of reinforcement learning (RL) with imitation learning (IL) can inspire innovations in audio processing models, particularly in tasks requiring adaptive behavior under uncertainty, similar to audio restoration challenges.
background: The study focuses on developing a robust autonomous driving policy using a combination of photorealistic environment simulations and reinforcement learning techniques to improve safety and effectiveness.
contribution: This paper introduces a 3D Gaussian Splatting-based reinforcement learning framework to solve the closed-loop training challenges in autonomous driving, achieving significantly lower collision rates compared to traditional methods.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Existing methods such as Imitation Learning often fail to generalize in complex environments due to causal confusion and limited exploration of state spaces.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work enhances training through a closed-loop RL paradigm, utilizing realistic simulations that allow for extensive exploration and robust learning from safety-critical scenarios.

key_innovation: The 3DGS framework enables the generation of detailed, interactive driving environments that improve the policy's ability to handle real-world variances and dynamics.
real_world_impact: By improving the collision-avoidance capabilities of autonomous vehicles, this work has the potential to significantly enhance road safety and the reliability of self-driving technology in urban environments.
limitations: While the approach shows promise in simulation, the authors acknowledge that the environments are currently non-reactive, which might not fully mimic real-world conditions.

new_terms.3D Gaussian Splatting (3DGS): **3D Gaussian Splatting** is a rendering technique used to create photorealistic visual representations of 3D environments by utilizing Gaussian distributions to model scene elements.
